questions.text: What does the marked region in the given spirometry represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked region in the given spirometry represents the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC).

  • Spirometry measures airflow in and out of the lungs, which is useful in diagnosing and monitoring lung diseases.
  • FRC is the lung air volume after a normal, passive exhalation. It is calculated as the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV) and is around 2.3 L.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after suddenly losing consciousness while working outdoors. On examination, his body temperature is 105°F, and he shows reduced skin turgor. Which of the following findings is least likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Although present in earlier stages of heat exhaustion, sweating typically stops in heat stroke, especially non-exertional heat stroke.

Physiological Changes in Heat Stroke

Heat stroke is a life-threatening condition marked by a core temperature >40°C, leading to CNS dysfunction and multi-organ failure.

Key Physiological Changes

  • Hyperthermia:
    • Core temperature rises above 40°C; cellular necrosis occurs at 49°C-50°C, red hot skin. (Option D ruled out)
  • CNS Dysfunction:
    • Symptoms: Confusion, agitation, seizures, coma.
    • Causes: Cerebral hypoperfusion, increased intracranial pressure, and systemic inflammation.
  • Cardiovascular Changes:
    • Tachycardia, hypotension, widened pulse pressure. (Option B ruled out)
    • Distributive shock due to vasodilation and vascular permeability.
  • Metabolic Disturbances:
    • Metabolic acidosis from anaerobic metabolism.
    • Electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyponatremia).
  • Inflammatory Response:
    • Cytokine release (e.g., IL-6) causes endothelial damage, microthrombosis, and DIC.
  • Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):
    • Causes: Rhabdomyolysis, dehydration, reduced renal perfusion.
  • Respiratory Changes:
    • Tachypnea compensates for metabolic acidosis. (Option A ruled out)
    • Kussmaul breathing reflects severe acidosis, indicating critical metabolic derangement.

Key Takeaways:

Reference:

  1. Heat stroke - PMC
  2. A Systematic Review on Outcomes of Patients with Heatstroke and Heat Exhaustion - PMC

questions.text: From the given graph, which pair of substances is correctly matched with their respective renal clearance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given graph shows renal clearance of different substances.

Clearance measures the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per minute (mL/min), reflecting renal excretory efficiency. It is essential for evaluating kidney function, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion processes.

To calculate the clearance rate (Cs) of the substance, use the formula:

Clearance Formula: (Cs) = (Us × V) / Ps

Us: Urine concentration of the substance

V: Urine flow rate

Ps: Plasma concentration of the substance

Plugging in the values:

Cs = (10 ×2)/5  = 4 ml /min

So, the clearance rate of the substance is 4 mL/min.

Types of Clearance Measurements:

Key Takeaways:

Renal Clearance

CPAH>>CCr>>CInsulin [125ml/min (GFR)]>>Curea>>CNa+>>CGlucose/AA

choices.text: The threshold point is at A
At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to the opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is a refractory period

questions.text: Which statement properly defines the nerve action potential curve provided?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given graph represents an action potential curve of a nerve. Point B to D represents the refractory period, a phase during which a second action potential is impossible or difficult to trigger.

This period includes the absolute refractory period (impossible to trigger a second action potential) and the relative refractory period (a second action potential can be triggered but requires a stronger stimulus).

Propagation of Action Potential:

  • Mechanism: Action potentials travel along the nerve fibre without diminishing. Depolarisation at one site causes local current flow that triggers action potentials in adjacent regions.
  • All-or-Nothing Principle: An action potential occurs only if the threshold is reached, maintaining consistent magnitude regardless of stimulus strength.

Refractory Periods: (Option D)

  • Absolute Refractory Period: Na+ channels are inactivated, preventing the generation of another action potential.
  • Relative Refractory Period: Requires a stronger stimulus to trigger another action potential due to partial repolarisation.

Myelination and Saltatory Conduction: The Myelin Sheath insulates nerve fibres, formed by Schwann cells. Action potentials "jump" between nodes of Ranvier, speeding up transmission and saving energy.

Energy Dependence: Na+-K+ Pump restores ionic gradients after an action potential, consuming ATP.

Factors Influencing Excitability:

  • Calcium Ions (Ca2+): Low extracellular Ca2+ increases excitability by lowering the activation threshold for Na+ channels; high Ca2+ decreases excitability.
  • Local Anaesthetics: Block voltage-gated Na+ channels, reducing excitability and preventing action potentials.

questions.text: What type of transport across the cell membrane is given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image represents facilitated diffusion, a passive transport that moves substances down their concentration gradient without using cellular energy, but requires the assistance of specific carrier proteins embedded in the cell membrane.

This process is essential for transporting large or polar molecules that cannot cross the cell membrane's lipid bilayer by simple diffusion.

Types of diffusion:

Explanation for other options:

Primary active transport (Option C): This active transport uses cellular energy (ATP) to transport substances against their concentration gradient. This process often involves specific carrier proteins, such as the Na+/K+ ATPase pump.

Secondary active transport (Option D): This type of active transport uses the energy stored in the form of ion concentration gradients, established by primary active transport, to drive the transport of other substances against their concentration gradient.

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm infant born at 28 weeks develops signs of respiratory distress syndrome. Which statement accurately describes the changes in surface tension and lung compliance in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Surface tension increased and compliance decreased; this statement is accurate regarding surface tension and compliance in a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension are the two opposing forces to lung compliance, and are not opposing forces to each other.

Two primary factors influence lung compliance:

  • Elastic forces of the lung tissue:
    • These forces are primarily determined by the presence of elastin and collagen fibres within the lung parenchyma (the functional tissue of the lungs).
    • In a deflated lung, these fibres are contracted and kinked. As the lung expands during inspiration, these fibres stretch and unkink, generating an elastic force that opposes further expansion.
  • Surface tension:
    • A thin layer of fluid lines the inside of the alveoli. At the air-fluid interface within the alveoli, surface tension arises from the stronger attraction between water molecules compared to the attraction between water molecules and air molecules.
    • This surface tension creates an inward pull, attempting to minimise the surface area of the fluid lining the alveoli. Consequently, this inward pull contributes to the elastic recoil of the lungs, making them tend to collapse.

Reference: Pulmonary Compliance - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

choices.text: First becomes more positive then negative

questions.text: A patient presents following a road traffic accident with significant muscle injury. Laboratory tests reveal a serum potassium level of 6.5 mEq/L. How is the resting membrane potential expected to change in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In hyperkalemia, where serum potassium levels are higher than normal (as in this patient with muscle injury), the concentration gradient of potassium ions across the cell membrane changes. The resting membrane potential in this patient becomes more positive.

RMP in hyperkalemia, hypokalemia and hypocalcemia

Hypocalcemia:

  • When blood calcium is normal or high, calcium remains bound to the extracellular mouth of voltage-gated Na+ channels, stabilising them.
  • Low blood Ca2+ (hypocalcemia) causes calcium to detach from the channel, leading to easier sodium entry. This detachment increases Na‚Å∫ channel sensitivity, enhancing excitability and action potential generation.
  • Calcium and magnesium act as membrane stabilisers.

Hyperkalemia can eventually lead to increased activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase pump as a compensatory mechanism; this is not a direct or immediate effect on the RMP.

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: In a patient with a cervical spine injury from a road traffic accident, a fracture fragment is found to have impinged on the lateral portion of the dorsal column tract. What clinical findings are most likely to be observed in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dorsal column tract of the spinal cord is responsible for proprioception, vibration sensation, and fine touch. The clinical findings likely observed in this case will be the absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception.

choices.text: Due to the opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to the slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to the closure of Na+and the opening of slow K+ channels

questions.text: What is the true statement regarding the segment marked in red on the myocardial action potential curve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The red mark on the myocardial action potential curve represents phase 2, the plateau phase of the cardiac action potential, which is due to the slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
